criteria: Ability to formulate relevant and focused questions about the advantages and disadvantages of digital vs. analog information transmission and storage.
Understanding of the relationship between wave properties and digital information transmission.
Ability to evaluate the impact of digital information technologies on society and modern civilization.
descriptions: Student does not formulate any questions or the questions are completely irrelevant to the topic.
Student formulates a question, but it is vague, unclear, or demonstrates a lack of understanding of digital information or wave properties.
Student formulates a question that touches on either advantages or disadvantages, but lacks depth or focus.
Student formulates questions addressing both advantages and disadvantages of digital transmission, but lacks critical evaluation.
Student formulates well-defined questions that critically evaluate the advantages and disadvantages of digital transmission and storage, showing an understanding of trade-offs.

Student formulates insightful and probing questions that challenge existing assumptions or explore nuanced aspects of digital information transmission and storage, demonstrating a sophisticated understanding of the topic.
Student demonstrates no understanding of wave properties or how they relate to digital information transmission.
Student shows a vague or inaccurate understanding of wave properties or the process of digital information transmission.
Student identifies wave properties but does not connect them to the process of transmitting digital information.
Student explains how digital information is sent as wave pulses but shows limited understanding of the underlying principles.
Student demonstrates a solid understanding of how wave properties (frequency, amplitude, etc.) are utilized in digital information transmission and storage.
Student provides a comprehensive explanation of the connection between wave properties and digital information, including error correction and modulation techniques.
Student does not address the influence of digital technologies on society.
Student mentions digital technologies but does not relate them to broader societal impacts.
Student describes some ways that digital technologies influence society but lacks depth or critical analysis.
Student analyzes the impact of digital technologies on society, providing examples of both benefits and drawbacks.
Student critically evaluates the influence of digital technologies, considering factors such as accessibility, security, and ethical considerations.
Student offers a nuanced perspective on the impact of digital technologies, exploring the complex interplay between technological advancements, societal changes, and ethical dilemmas.
